 It is hard to really assign blame in a disaster such as this. Every disaster is made up of a chain of events, not one single event. You could look at it this way.
 1. The city was built in a poor area (below sea level in a hurricane prone area).
 2. We destroyed a lot of marsh land that once would have helped protect the area.
 3. The city did not contain adequate or up to date safeguards to prevent or mitigate the flooding.
 4. The storm was extremely powerful.
 5. Many people ignored evacuation orders.
 6. A rescue effort of this magnitude takes a long time to organize.
 7. The city appeared to have been spared from major damage, until the levee broke.
 8. People are hampering the rescue effort by looting, not proceeding to evac areas, shooting at boats, police, helo's, etc.
 9. This type of rescue and relief effort is rather uncharted territory for the US.
 
 There are many other factors that could be listed, this is only a smattering of the most obvious.
